column2: Answer: Gluten sensitivity, also known as non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), is a condition that involves a person being sensitive to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Individuals with gluten sensitivity may experience symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and headaches after consuming gluten. Unlike celiac disease, there is no test or biomarker for diagnosing gluten sensitivity. Treatment for this condition typically involves following a strict gluten-free diet and avoiding wheat, barley, and rye.

The acronym SOA stands for Service-Oriented Architecture. It is a method of designing and organizing software systems as autonomous services that communicate with each other, creating a single framework to integrate applications across different organizations. SOA is used to design distributed and decentralized applications, making it easier for businesses to change and integrate legacy systems with new ones.

Gluten sensitivity (also known as non-celiac gluten sensitivity) is a medical condition in which people experience unpleasant symptoms after eating food containing gluten, a type of protein found in wheat, barley and rye. Symptoms can range from gastrointestinal distress to headaches, fatigue and skin rashes. Unlike celiac disease, a severe autoimmune disorder, gluten sensitivity does not cause lasting damage to the intestine.
